snippet: Only a fraction of an estimated $60 billion in fraud and overcharging was recovered last year, and the system to combat fraud may be largely to blame.
abstract: Obama administration's declared war on health care fraud is returning only meager results, despite escalation, recovering about $4.3 billion of an estimated $60 billion in 2013; interviews reveal that sprawling effort relies on an array of poorly-managed outside contractors, rife with conflicts of interest and vulnerable to political influence.

byline.original: By REED ABELSON and ERIC LICHTBLAU

lead_paragraph: Only a fraction of an estimated $60 billion in fraud and overcharging was recovered last year, and the system to combat fraud may be largely to blame.

headline.main: Pervasive Medicare Fraud Proves Hard to Stop
headline.print_headline: Pervasive Medicare Fraud Proves Hard to Stop

keywords.value: Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services
keywords.name: organizations
